_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ulk storage tanks, evaporators, chlorinators, residual analyzers, ejectors, diffusers, chlorine contact tanks, piping and other equipment.  The capacity of each chlorine bulk storage tank is 25 tons; however, the maximum quantity of chlorine present in a tank at any given time is only 18 tons.  In case of a major chlorine leak, the bulk storage tanks and the chlorine tank trailer can be isolated by the emergency shutoff valves located on the piping downstream of the bulk storage tank manway and at the end of the flexible hoses that connect to the tank trailer.  There are emergency shutdown switches (push buttons) located at each door into the chlorine building, and on the chlorine shutdown (emergency) valve control panel located on the mezzanine of the chlorine transfer area.  On the chlorine shutdown (emergency) valve control panel, there are individual control switches for each valve.  All emergency shutdown valves can also be activated from the Plant Control Room. 
Chlorine gas detectors are used to detect a chlorine leak in the bulk storage and chlorinator rooms.  Upon detection of approximately 0.5 parts per millions by volume (ppmv) chlorine, the detectors will send a signal which will shut down the normal ventilation system to contain the chlorine gas within the chlorination and storage rooms.  The caustic scrubber system is automatically activated in the event of a chlorine leak.

The sulfur dioxide systems at LCWRP consist of two sulfur dioxide bulk storage tanks, evaporators, sulfonators, residual analyzers, ejectors, diffusers, and piping and other equipment.  The capacity of each sulfur dioxide bulk storage tank is 20 tons; however, the maximum quantity of sulfur dioxide present in a tank at any given time is only 17 tons.  In case of a major sulfur dioxide leak, the bulk storage tanks and the sulfur dioxide tank trailer can be isolated by the emergency shutoff valves located on the piping downstream of the bulk storage tank manway and at the end of t

97 under the RMPP and PSM Program as part of an update.  In 1999, as part of its compliance with the US EPA RMP and California RMP programs CSDLAC conducted PHA updates for the storage, handling and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at LCWRP.  Furthermore, in 2004 and 2009, CSDLAC conducted a PHA on the storage, handling and use of aqueous ammonia at LCWRP.  ALL recommended actions resulting from these PHAs and PHA Updates have been implemented as required.  

As part of the 2014 Five-Year RMP Update and Revalidation, PHA updates were conducted for the storage, handling and use of chlorine, sulfur dioxide and aqueous ammonia.  Based on this review, additional recommended actions have been identified to further improve the safety of chlorine, sulfur dioxide systems and aqueous ammonia storage, handling and use systems.  The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of these systems.

CSDLAC has initiated preliminary design for the conversion of the existing chlorine and sulfur dioxide chemical facilities at LCWRP to sodium hypochlorite and sodium bisulfite chemical facilities.  The emergency caustic scrubbers at each facility shall also be decommissioned as part of each project.  This project is expected to be completed by the next submission date in 2019.

ic users in the region; a small fraction is of industrial origin.  Wastewater treatment utilizes the activated sludge process with aqueous ammonia addition, chlorination, and dechlorination to yield a tertiary effluent that is suitable for re-use.

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY COMPONENTS

Storing and handling large quantities of aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide can create hazardous situations.  For this reason, LCWRP follows all industry recommended practices for safely storing and handling these chemicals.  LCWRP's aqueous ammonia handling processes are subject to the CalARP Program Level 2 Requirements.  LCWRP's chlorine and sulfur dioxide handling processes are subject to the US EPA RMP and to the CalARP Program Level 3 requirements.  These programs require a summary in the RMP of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 
  ¿ Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
  ¿ General facility and regulated substances information.
  ¿ Offsite consequence analysis results. 
  ¿ Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
  ¿ Five-year accident history summary.
  ¿ Emergency response program summary.
  ¿ Planned changes to improve safety.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

CSDLAC's accidental release prevention policy at LCWRP involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

The CSDLAC emergency respo

The County Sanitation Districts of Los Angeles County (CSDLAC) owns and operates the Los Coyotes Water Reclamation Plant (LCWRP).  The LCWRP is located at 16515 Piuma Avenue in Cerritos, California 90703, and stores a maximum of 72,000-pounds of chlorine at any one time (contained in two 25-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), a maximum of 68,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide at any one time (contained in two 20-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), and a maximum of 95,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia (19.5 percent [%] concentration) at any one time (contained in three 3,800 gallon above-ground tanks located outdoors). 

Due to the quantities of chlorine, sulfur dioxide and aqueous ammonia stored, handled and used at the site, LCWRP is subject to requirements specified in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (US EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations (Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68), the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Articles 1 through 11), and the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (29 CFR Part 1910.119).  

GENERAL FACILITY INFORMATION 

The primary operation conducted at the LCWRP is the treatment of wastewater (NAICS Code 22132 - Sewage Treatment Facilities).  The treatment facility is located on a land area of approximately 34 acres, bounded on the south side by the Artesia (91) Freeway, on the east side by the San Gabriel River Valley (605) Freeway, on the north and west sides by Cerritos Iron Wood Nine golf course.  

The CSDLAC has operated the LCWRP facility since inception in 1970.  The design treatment capacity of the plant has increased from an original capacity of 12.5 million gallons per day (mgd) to its current capacity of 37.5 mgd.  The wastewater treated at LCWRP originates mainly from approximately 370,000 domest

nse policy involves the preparation of Hazardous Materials and Hazardous Waste Consolidated Contingency Plans (HMHWCCP) for handling hazardous materials which are specific for each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program requirements.  The CSDLAC has prepared a HMHWCCP for the LCWRP for storing and handling hazardous materials, including aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The HMHWCCP has been coordinated with the local response agency, the County of Los Angeles Fire Department (LACFD).  The LCWRP has an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Aqueous ammonia (19.5% concentration) is used to maintain the disinfection limits in the treated effluent.  The aqueous ammonia is provided by delivery truck and transferred via hose to the ammonia storage tanks.  The aqueous ammonia solution is stored in 30 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) design, American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Code unfired pressure vessels.  There are three 3,800-gallon tanks at LCWRP.  The working capacity of each tank is approximately 3,040 gallons, and each tank is provided with a high level alarm.  The aqueous ammonia is then transferred from the storage tanks to dosing locations within the effluent channel and mixed.  Once the aqueous ammonia is mixed with the treated effluent, CalARP regulations no longer apply.

Chlorine used for chlorination at LCWRP and is received in chlorine trailers and transferred to bulk storage tanks located inside the buildings.  Sulfur dioxide used for dechlorination is also received at LCWRP in sulfur dioxide trailers and transferred to storage tanks located inside the buildings.  The chlorination systems at LCWRP consist of two chlorine b

can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.  A list of worst-case scenarios is in Table 1 below.

TABLE 1: LCWRP WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS
  RELEASE SCENARIO	        CHEMICAL	TYPE OF RELEASE
  Worst-Case Scenario (OCA 1)	Aqueous Ammonia	Instantaneous release from largest storage tank/vessel on-site.
  Worst-case Scenario (OCA 3)	Chlorine	Instantaneous release from largest storage tank/vessel on-site.
  Worst-case Scenario (OCA 5)	Sulfur Dioxide	Instantaneous release from largest storage tank/vessel on-site.

Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary

Three alternative case release scenarios were modeled, one for each covered chemical.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.  A list of alternative case scenarios is in Table 2 below.

TABLE 2: LCWRP ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
  RELEASE SCENARIO	        CHEMICAL	TYPE OF RELEASE
  Alternative Release (OCA 2)	Aqueous Ammonia	Ammonia truck transfer.
  Alternative Release (OCA 4)	Chlorine	Flexible hose release
  Alternative Release (OCA 6)	Sulfur Dioxide	Flexible hose release

RISK CONSIDERATIONS

Although the use of chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and aqueous ammonia for the water reclamation process has inherent potential risks, and worst case release scenarios can potentially reach the community, LCWRP has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

LCWRP is in compliance with Federal and State PSM requirements.  LCWRP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements: 
  ¿ Deta

he flexible hoses that connect to the tank trailer.  Similar to the chlorine system, there are emergency shutdown switches on the sulfur dioxide system.
Sulfur dioxide gas detectors are used to detect a sulfur dioxide leak in the bulk storage room and sulfonator room.  Upon detection of approximately 5 ppmv sulfur dioxide, the detectors will send a signal, which will shut down the normal ventilation system to contain the gas within the sulfonator and storage room.  The caustic scrubber system is automatically activated in the event of a sulfur dioxide leak.

The scrubber system is equipped with an emergency generator set.  The emergency generator will automatically start powering in the event of a power failure and will continue to run for 5 minutes after regular power is restored.  The emergency generator powers the entire scrubbing system including, local alarms, caustic recirculation pumps, electrically-operated valves and the sump pump.  The generator also powers portions of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems including the automatic shutoff valve system (including the air compressors), lighting in both areas as well as lighting in the scrubber area, gas detectors, and the building ventilation fans. 

LCWRP is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through sliding main gate, which is always closed.  All hours access is through remote operation of the gate by an operator who verifies the identity of the visitor at the gate.  A two-way intercom system and a closed circuit television allow operators to communicate with and monitor visitors from the control building.  The buildings that house the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems are normally alarmed and locked except when operators and maintenance personnel are working.  

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst case analysis has been defined for each covered process.  The results

iled management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
  ¿ Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
  ¿ Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
  ¿ Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
  ¿ Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
  ¿ Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
  ¿ High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
  ¿ Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include the awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of aqueous ammonia and the remotely-controlled shutoff valves on the ammonia transfer trucks.  Chemical-specific prevention steps include the use of supplied air respirators (SAR) and self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine/sulfur dioxide supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine/sulfur dioxide, presence of chlorine/sulfur dioxide detectors and alarms, remotely-controlled shutoff valves, and chlorine/sulfur dioxide scrubbers. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by LCWRP to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and aqueous ammonia.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  

The Prevention Program (Program Level 2 and Level 3) elements are summarized in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook developed for the facility, and include:
  ¿ Safety Information/Process Safety Information,
  ¿ Hazard Revie

w/Process Hazard Analysis,
  ¿ Operating Procedures,
  ¿ Training,
  ¿ Mechanical Integrity,
  ¿ Management of Change,
  ¿ Pre-Startup Safety Review,
  ¿ Compliance Audits,
  ¿ Incident Investigation,
  ¿ Employee Participation,
  ¿ Hot Work Permit, and 
  ¿ Contractors.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The accident history can be found in the documentation located behind the Incident Investigation Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.  No reportable accidents have occurred at the LCWRP facility in the last five years, since 2009.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

LCWRP-trained operators are first responders to aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide leak alarms and accidental releases.  Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external resources such as the LACFD will be called upon to aid in handling an aqueous ammonia, chlorine, or sulfur dioxide release.  As part of the emergency response program, CSDLAC has developed and implemented HMHWCCPs for both facilities for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  The HMHWCCPs have been coordinated with the local response agency (LACFD).  The main elements of each emergency response plan are: (1) initial discovery equipment and procedure, (2) response to an emergency, including procedures for immediate action and internal notifications, (3) procedures for external notifications, including coordination with Local Governments, Incident Commanders, (4) incident action plan, including mitigation actions, response resources, (5) implementation of tactical plan, and (6) termination and follow-up actions. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In 1990, as part of its compliance with the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP), numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified for the storage, handling and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide as part of the PHAs conducted at the LCWRP.
